newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes steady, Tapis boost amid shut-ins.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes steady, Tapis boost amid shut-ins.

text.p: Crude prices in Asia held steady on Tuesday but light sweet grades firmed as Australian production was hit by Cyclone Phil.
Operators of the 90,000 barrels per day (bpd) Cossack and 70,000 bpd Griffin fields shut down Monday and at least one major could face a scheduling disruption because of the shut down, traders said.
Barrow Island was producing but not berthing and the Wandoo field, which produces a heavy crude, was shut in.
Operators and traders said the fields could look to restart by the end of the week.
Traders said the shut downs played into the hands of the Tapis market, where a producer sold 300,000 barrels of first half February crude to a European major at a premium of $1.60.
The European major is making up a full cargo of 600,000 to 650,000 barrels of Tapis, which is destined for a joint-venture refinery in China.
The producer is now offering its February barrels at $1.70 premium -- supported by the Australian stoppages.
Elsewhere, futures prices languished on SIMEX with nothing traded and only an offer shown on the most active February contract.
NYMEX February crude, trading on ACCESS, was steady at $25.36, down just one cent from the New York close.
Brent/Dubai spreads were wide, with February offered at $2.00 and a notional bid put at $1.80.
February/March Dubai was firmer but wide at 50/65 cents from 50/55 in New York.
